Description: Body sherd of Chian Mature Animal Style pottery cup, possibly a phallus cup; on the inside near the bottom of the sherd there is a spur, as if of a handle root; white slip; interior glazed streaky black; possible faded added white line above part of lotus bud in white outline with added red centre and white tendril; exterior: painted decoration consisting of sphinx to left (body, trace of wing, haunch, paw and tail remaining); elaborate cross, rosettes, blob and rising roundel as filling ornament; below, row of dots between lines and part of a second one.
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as belonging to the Group of Light-Walled Naukratis Animal Chalices. All sherds in this group are small and offer very little by way of information beyond the fact that they come from light-walled chalices. The decoration on sherds belonging to this group is also poorly or carelessly drawn (Lemos 1991, 93). Although identified by Lemos as a chalice, Williams points out that the sherd has a significantly different profile from that of a chalice, as the vessel narrows, but clearly continues, near the bottom of the sherd. He suggests that the sherd may have formed the top portion of a phallus cup (Williams 2006a, 128). For a similar spur, this time complete, see British Museum 1924,1201.203, which comes from a closely similar pot.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 93, p. 258, no. 480, pl. 65)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p.128, fig.2, no.23)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1936) (phase 2)
